name: desulfurisation of lignite flue gas | SOx retained, in lignite flue gas desulfurisation | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/6270/documentation

This dataset represents the flue gas desulfurisation process of a lignite power plant per 1 kg SOx retained. The efficiency of the desulfurisation is 90%.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Desulfurisation process starting with the operation of a lignite power plant.

This activity ends with 1 kg retained SOx resulting from the flue gas desulfurisation process of a coal power plant. The dataset includes the materials. The dataset doesn’t include the waste water emissions and the solid waste and doesn’t include the gypsum as a byproduct. The waste water is used for keeping wet the ash from the operation of the plant and is disposed with the bottom ash and fly ash (Gerhard et al. 1989). 100% of the radioactive elements K-40, Ra-226, Pb-214, Bi-214, Ac-228, Pb-212, Bi-212 and Tl-208 are separated with the bottom ash and fly ash (Merz et al. 1989).

References:
Gebhard G., Lukas W., Bambauer H.U. (1989) Stabilisierung von Rückständen aus der Braunkohleentschwefelung. In: VGB Kraftwerkstechnik 69, Heft 4, 1989, s.384-392.
Merz E., Kroth K., Scholz W., Holzapfel Th. (1989) Radioaktivitätsmessung an Gips aus Rauchgasentschwefelungsanlagen (REA) und Aktivitätsbilanzierung des Rauchgasentschwefelungsprozesses eines mit rheinischer Braunkohle befeuerten Grosskraftwerkes. In: VGB Kraftwerkstechnik 69, Heft 11, s.1114-1118.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data for an average European desulfurisation plant.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: About 85% of the installed capacity of desulphurization plants are installed as scrubber with lime or limestone (Vernon et al. 1990). Due to the relevance of lignite power plants in the western states of Germany, the current proportion of desulfurisation with limestone is assumed with 100%.  The additional consumption of electricity and heat for the desulfurisation process is taken into account in the net efficiency. ;The process steps are the detergent treatment, the absorption of flue gas components in the scrubbing suspension, the oxidation to sulfate (HSO3- to SO4-), the neutralization of the water suspension by the addition of limestone, crystallization of the gypsum, separation of the gypsum crystal from the mother liquor, calcination, pelleting or briquetting of gypsum for further use (IPP 1990, Baum 1988).;With limestone (CaCO3), the gases SO2, SO3, HCl and HF are absorbed in a scrubbing solution. Limestone has a low reactivity, but is preferred compared with quicklime (CaO) and slaked lime (Ca(OH)2 for economic reasons (IIP 1990). The de-dusted flue gas is either cooled in a pre-scrubber or directly cooled in the absorber. There, the hydrogen halides, the residual dust particulates and up to 20% of the SO2 are washed out. The suspension from the pre-scrubber can also be removed separately. Thus, mixing with the gypsum can be prevented. Droplet separators retain entrained liquid droplets and the clean gas is reheated and discharged through the chimney. By air intake oxidation is encouraged in the scrubber sump to form the gypsum. ;The pH-value, the ratio of the absorption liquid to the amount of exhaust gas and the concentration of absorption liquid significantly affect the separation efficiency. In (Hövelmann 1987) an efficiency of 95% is quantified. In other sources, this value is estimated at 80%. In the EU a value of 90% is obligatory, which can be achieved with a scrubber with limestone.;References:;Vernon J.L., Soud H.N. (1990) FGD installations on coal-fired plants. IEA Coal Research, London.;IIP Karlsruhe, Ministerium für Umwelt Baden-Württemberg (1990) Entsorgung von Reststoffen aus der Rauchgasreinigung; Teil 2: TA Luft-Feuerungsanlagen. Karlsruhe.;Baum F. (1988) Luftreinhaltung in der Praxis. München, Deutschland.;Hövelmann A. (1987) Neue Entsorgungsprobleme kohlegefeuerter Kraftwerke. Jül-2172, KFA Jülich.

exchanges.description: EcoSpold01Location=GLO

flow.name: SOx retained, in lignite flue gas desulfurisation
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description: Literature value. Ecoinvent 2 report 6 VI pag. 125 table 9.33. Tab. 9.32 (Verschiedene REA-Bilanzen aus diversen Quellen) and Tab. 9.33, p.126f in Röder et al. (2007): REA-Massenbilanz pro kg reduziertes SO2, REA-Nass nach Tab. 9.33, REA-Nass Brk-D (Nass-Entschwefelung der westdeutschen Braunkohlekraftwerke). The tables are compilations of different sources for wet flue-gas desulfurisation mass-balances. Tab.9.33 shows the mass balance values chosen for this dataset.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. The water for the desulfurisation process does not need to meet any higher demands and corresponds to the quality of cooling water. 

Further references:
Uerpmann E.-P. (1990) Betriebserfahrungen mit nasser Rauchgasentschwefelung in Braunkohlekraftwerken. In: VGB-Seminar Rauchgasreinigung und Reststoffentsorgung in Kraftwerken, Industrie- und Heizkraftwerken. Cottbus, Deutschland.


Estimation. The water for the desulfurisation process does not need to meet any higher demands and corresponds to the quality of cooling water.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Estimation. The reaction equation of the limestone process is CaCO3 + 2H2O + SO2 + _O2 -> CaSO4 • 2H2O + CO2. For lime processes stoichiometrically only 0.9 kg of lime per kg of SO2 is necessary and no additional CO2 is produced. CO2 already escaped during the calcination of lime.

Further references:
Uerpmann E.-P. (1990) Betriebserfahrungen mit nasser Rauchgasentschwefelung in Braunkohlekraftwerken. In: VGB-Seminar Rauchgasreinigung und Reststoffentsorgung in Kraftwerken, Industrie- und Heizkraftwerken. Cottbus, Deutschland.

The tables are compilations of different sources for wet flue-gas desulfurisation mass-balances. Tab.9.33 shows the mass balance values chosen for this dataset.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. The water for the desulfurisation process does not need to meet any higher demands and corresponds to the quality of cooling water. 

Further references:
Uerpmann E.-P. (1990) Betriebserfahrungen mit nasser Rauchgasentschwefelung in Braunkohlekraftwerken. In: VGB-Seminar Rauchgasreinigung und Reststoffentsorgung in Kraftwerken, Industrie- und Heizkraftwerken. Cottbus, Deutschland.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The reaction equation of the limestone process is CaCO3 + 2H2O + SO2 + _O2 -> CaSO4 • 2H2O + CO2. For lime processes stoichiometrically only 0.9 kg of lime per kg of SO2 is necessary and no additional CO2 is produced. CO2 already escaped during the calcination of lime.

Further references:
Uerpmann E.-P. (1990) Betriebserfahrungen mit nasser Rauchgasentschwefelung in Braunkohlekraftwerken. In: VGB-Seminar Rauchgasreinigung und Reststoffentsorgung in Kraftwerken, Industrie- und Heizkraftwerken. Cottbus, Deutschland.
